co-first authors and contributed equally to this work. S-doped graphene supported SACs exhibited better catalytic performance for many heterogeneous reactions with adjustable electronic properties of single-atom active center. This work investigates C2H2 selective hydrogenation on a series of S-doped graphene supported SACs to unravel the roles of single-atom type and its coordination environment in tuning catalytic performance. It is found that the intrinsic reasons affecting catalytic activity are attributed to that different metal M type and its coordination environment led to different Bader charge transfer and d-band center, and further affect adsorption ability of reactants and intermediates to tune catalytic performance. The descriptor φ=(χM+ࣥdnSχS)+N d was constructed in the S-doped graphene supported SACs, which can quickly and qualitatively evaluate C2H4 formation activity and selectivity, and further increase design efficiency of high-performance SACs. The screened Os/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts not only exhibit good selectivity, activity and ability to inhibit green oil, but also present good structural and thermal stability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords S-doped graphene Single-atom catalyst Metal types Coordination environment C2H2 selective hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Industrially, ethylene (C2H4) is mainly derived from the cracking of naphtha [1], accompanied by the production of trace amounts of acetylene (C2H2). At present, C2H2 selective hydrogenation is a conventional method to remove traces of C2H2 [2]. Pd-based catalysts have been widely used to present higher low-temperature catalytic activity. However, both over-hydrogenation and polymerization reactions easily occur to reduce C2H4 selectivity and deactivate catalyst [3]. It is well known that different electronic and geometric properties of active sites led to different adsorption behaviors of the intermediates [4,5]. Over Pd surface, C2H4 has three adsorption forms at the triple site by ethyl, at the double site by di-σ bond and at the isolated Pd single-atom by π bond. The adsorption strength of these three forms decreases sequentially [6]. The π-bonded adsorption mode facilitates C2H4 desorption and avoids its excessive hydrogenation to C2H6 [7]. Thus, it is an effective strategy to improve C2H4 selectivity by designing a single-atom catalyst with highly dispersed active sites to weaken C2H4 adsorption ability. Single-atom catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance due to their extremely high atomic utilization. However, the high surface free energy makes single-atom aggregation to form nanoparticles under high temperature, thus, a suitable support is necessary for anchoring single-atom [8,9]. Since N atom has higher electronegativity and one more valence electron than C atom, the electron pairs can be introduced into graphene π-conjugated system, which can adjust electron interaction with single-atom metal to enhance catalytic performance [10–12]. Thus, N-doped graphene (M-Nx) and its supported SACs have been widely reported. Furthermore, the introduction of S atom into graphene breaks the original symmetric structure to changes adsorption configuration and electronic properties of reaction intermediate at the metal single-atom site [13–17]. For example, Tang et al. [16] constructed Co-N3S SACs, which shows an electron density increase of active Co center, a downward shift of d -band center and a decrease in the anti-bond state energy level; as a result, the energy barrier of H* diffusion and quinoline hydrogenation is greatly decreased to improve catalytic activity. Zhao et al. [17] found that the electronic properties of Mo atoms in a series of Mo SACs (Mo-N4 C, Mo-O4 C, Mo-S4 C, Mo-S2O2 C) are affected by the coordination environment, in which the synergistic effect of S/O in the Mo-S2O2 C weakens O* adsorption strength to exhibit better ORR activity. The introduction of S atom into graphene not only change the species adsorption strength, but also change electronic state of surrounding C atom, which is activated to be the active center of targeted reaction [18]; meanwhile, the coordinated S atom also co-operate with metal atom to improve reactivity. For example, for N2 electrocatalytic reduction to NH3 [19], the Ru atom is coordinated with four S atoms, Ru favored N2 adsorption and activation, and S atoms facilitate H* adsorption; Ru atoms push electrons to the anti-bonding orbital of N2, and the H* binding with S atoms will also push electrons to N2, thus, the electronic ‘push-push’ effect achieve N2 synergistic activation. Compared with PdN4, the Pd in the PdS4 loses more electrons and is closer to metallic state, which shows nucleophilicity and promotes the desorption of styrene with a nucleophilic π electron cloud from catalyst surface, exhibiting high olefin selectivity [20]. Yan et al. [21] suggest that the interaction between metal Pt and S-C support leads to the electron redistribution between the metal and the support; when Pt exists as a single-atom, the Pt atom donates electrons to the S-C support; when the Pt cluster size reaches 1.5 nm, the S-C support donates electrons to Pt cluster, which is attributed to the increased electron affinity of Pt cluster and the downward shift of d -band center to enhance their electron trapping ability, and this inversion phenomenon of charge transfer occurs only at the S-C support. Wang et al. [22] synthesized an atom-dispersed catalyst with a metal loading of up to 10 % by using meso‑S-C as a support, this support has abundant and accessible S sites, which anchors metal atoms through strong metal-S interactions, so it exhibits excellent sintering resistance at high temperature 1100 °C. Above analysis shows that the introduction of S atoms into graphene can stably anchor metal single-atom and exhibit better catalytic performance toward targeted reactions. However, up to now, C2H2 selective hydrogenation on the S-doped graphene supported SACs have been rarely investigated, and the roles of single-atom metal M type and its coordination environment in tuning C2H4 formation activity, selectivity and catalyst stability are still unclear. In this work, based on DFT calculations and ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, the mechanism of C2H2 selective hydrogenation on a series of S-doped graphene supported metal SACs is examined, different doped metals and two coordination environments are considered to clarify the roles of single-atom metal M type and its coordination environment in tuning C2H4 selectivity, activity and catalyst stability. The obtained results are desired to provide valuable structural clues, which help designing and screening SACs with excellent performance and stable structure. 2 Computational details 2.1 Computational methods The calculations in this work are implemented in the VASP (Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package) [23,24]. To handle electron exchange interactions, the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) method within generalized gradient approximation (GGA) framework is used [25]. The plane-wave cutoff energy of 400 eV has been set along with the Brillouin zone k-point of 2 × 2 × 1. Van Der Waals interaction is considered by means of applying the DFT-D correction method [26,27]. A vacuum gap of 15 Å is positioned between the periodic images in the z direction. For all structural optimizations, the convergence accuracy for the force and energy are 0.02 eV·Å-1 and 1 × 10–5 eV, respectively [28]. The methods of CI-NEB [29–33] and Dimer [34–37] are used to search transition state (TS), and the final convergence accuracy is 0.05 eV·Å −1. The reliability of TS is confirmed by imaginary frequency. The spin-polarized calculations have been performed [38,39]. Given that C2H2 selective hydrogenation often takes place at the temperature range of 385∼456 K [40], the energies reported in this work are standardized to 425 K. 2.2 Catalyst models For S-doped graphene supported metal SACs, it is widely reported that four S atoms exist in the five-membered ring structure with the form of C-S-C, namely, thiophene sulfur [41,42]. For example, Perazzolo et al. [43] have prepared S-doped carbon using dibenzothiophene as post-doping, indicating that sulfur not only served as an anchoring site, but also promoted the formation of micropore and mesopore on the carbon support [44]. Meanwhile, the direct thermal treatment of graphene oxide with H2S at high temperature could also achieve sulfur doping in the form of thiophene-like sulfur species, resulting in S-doped graphene sheets with excellent electrocatalytic activity, long life, and high selectivity for ORR [45]. Regardless of the type of precursor material and the temperature employed during the carbonization process, the sulfur atoms introduced as dopants predominantly present a five-membered ring configuration, specifically in the form of carbon-sulfur-carbon (C-S-C) bonds, regarded as the structure of thiophene sulfur [46,47]. A hexagonal p(7 × 7) graphene supercell is firstly constructed, then, a multi-vacancy graphene is formed by removing six C atoms, followed by substituting four nearby C atoms with S atoms to create a thiophene-sulfur coordinated graphene, named as phe-S4-G. On the other hand, since the stability and electronic structure of metal single-atom can be changed by regulating micro-environment, four S atoms in the six-membered ring structure is also considered, namely, thiopyran sulfur. For example, Tang et al. [48] have prepared an active Co1-S4/NC catalyst to exhibit high activity and stability in the hydrogen evolution reaction, the Co atoms in the Co1-S4/NC catalyst are directly coordinated with four S atoms of N-doped carbon support, and four S atoms are located in a six-membered ring structure, known as the structure of thiopyran sulfur. By constructing a hexagonal p(7 × 7) graphene supercell, a multi-vacancy graphene is formed by removing two C atoms, followed by substituting four nearby C atoms with S atoms to create a thiopyran-sulfur coordinated graphene [48], named as pyr-S4-G. 12 kinds of transition metals from the 3d period including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu; the 4d period including Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag and the 5d period including Os, Ir, Pt, Au are selected to construct S-doped graphene supported SACs with two kinds of coordination environment, named as M/phe-S4-G and M/pyr-S4-G, respectively. The most stable structures for above 24 types of catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural stability evaluation of the constructed catalysts Previous works by Wen et al. [42] and Zhang et al. [49] have used the binding energy to evaluate the structure stability of metal atoms over S-doped graphene, and Chen et al. [50] evaluated structure stability of Fe atoms over N, P, S-doped porous graphene using the binding energy. Thus, this work also evaluates structure stability of SACs through the binding energy (E b). A negative E b signifies a stable catalyst, which can avoid the aggregation of metal atoms. A positive E b signifies an unstable catalyst to facilitate metal atom aggregation. (1) E b = E M − sub − E s u b − E M Where E M-sub is the energy of M/phe-S4-G or M/pyr-S4-G catalyst; E sub is the energy of phe-S4-G or pyr-S4-G support; E M is the energy of metal M atom. The binding energies of 24 SACs are listed in Table S1. As illustrated in Fig. 2 , both M/pyr-S4-G and M/phe-S4-G catalysts exhibit high structure stability, especially the Ir/phe-S4-G and Os/pyr-S4-G catalyst. Meanwhile, the M/pyr-S4-G catalysts are more stable than the M/phe-S4-G catalysts. 3.2 The adsorption of H and C2Hx (x = 2∼5) species In industry, the removal of trace C2H2 (0.1∼1 %) is implemented in C2H4-rich feedstock [51], to achieve the effective C2H2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, it is necessary to ensure that the catalysts can have the stronger adsorption ability toward C2H2 rather than C2H4 on the 24 types of SACs. As shown in Fig. 3 a, among 12 SACs with phe-S4-G coordination, 5 SACs Rh/phe-S4-G, Pd/phe-S4-G, Ag/phe-S4-G, Os/phe-S4-G and Au/phe-S4-G have lower adsorption free energy of C2H2 than C2H4, which is not conducive to C2H2 adsorption. While 7 SACs Fe/phe-S4-G, Co/phe-S4-G, Ni/phe-S4-G, Cu/phe-S4-G, Ru/phe-S4-G, Ir/phe-S4-G and Pt/phe-S4-G have higher adsorption free energy of C2H2 than C2H4. As shown in Fig. 3b, among 12 SACs with pyr-S4-G coordination, C2H2 adsorption free energies over Co/pyr-S4-G and Ni/pyr-S4-G are positive at 425 K, so C2H2 is not easily adsorbed. Both Ag/pyr-S4-G and Au/pyr-S4-G catalysts have lower adsorption free energy of C2H2 than C2H4, which is not conducive to C2H2 adsorption. Only 8 SACs Fe/pyr-S4-G, Cu/pyr-S4-G, Ru/pyr-S4-G, Rh/pyr-S4-G, Pd/pyr-S4-G, Os/pyr-S4-G, Ir/pyr-S4-G and Pt/pyr-S4-G have higher C2H2 adsorption ability than C2H4. Thus, among 24 types of SACs, C2H2 can be preferentially adsorbed on the above 15 SACs. As mentioned above, the metal atoms in the 3d period exhibit stronger C2H2 adsorption ability in the phe-S4-G coordination environment, while the metal atoms in the 4d and 5d periods present stronger C2H2 adsorption ability in the pyr-S4-G coordination environment. Previous studies [52] showed that the metals from the 3d period, such as Fe, Co and Ni, exhibit higher reactivity in the phe-S4-G coordination environment due to the unfilled 3d orbital electrons, as a result, the 3d orbitals of these metals can form strong interactions with the π electrons of C2H2 [53], thereby enhancing C2H2 adsorption ability. Meanwhile, the ionic radius of 3d period metals is relatively small, allowing them to better coordinate with the S atoms in thiophene, and stabilize C2H2 molecule and further enhance C2H2 adsorption ability. In contrast, for the metals from the 4d and 5d periods, such as Rh and Pd, they have a greater number of d-orbital electrons, and their d-orbitals have better extensibility [52]. This allows them to form more dispersed and diverse coordination bonds in the pyr-S4-G coordination environment. Compared to phe-S4-G, pyr-S4-G provides a more suitable coordination environment, enabling 4d and 5d period metals to interact with C2H2 molecules more effectively. The d-orbital electrons of these metals can better interact with the π orbitals of C2H2, thereby enhancing C2H2 adsorption ability [54]. Moreover, the ionic radius of 4d and 5d period metals are relatively large, which matches well with the coordination environment of pyr-S4-G, contributing to the formation of stronger metal-sulfur bonds [39], which is also one of the reasons to exhibit stronger C2H2 adsorption ability in the pyr-S4-G environment [55]. On the other hand, some SACs fail to preferentially adsorb C2H2 over C2H4, it is primarily attributed to the competitive adsorption of these molecules on the SACs affected by the molecular structure and electronic properties [56]. Firstly, C2H2 and C2H4 have different chemical structures [57], C2H2 is a linear molecule with a triple bond, whereas C2H4 is a planar molecule with a double bond. This structural difference affects their interaction with the catalyst surface. The elongated C2H2 molecule and steric repulsion from the triple bond may limit its adsorption sites on certain catalyst surface. In contrast, C2H4 with its planar double bond configuration may have more contact points on the catalyst surface, leading to its stronger adsorption. As a result, C2H4 tends to adsorb more readily than C2H2. Secondly, the electronic structure of different metals in SACs can also affect the competitive adsorption between C2H2 and C2H4 [58], the π-bond structures and electron densities of these molecules differ. For certain SACs, the interaction between the catalyst's d-orbital electron and the π-electron cloud of these molecules may be more suitable for the electronic structure of C2H4, resulting in higher C2H4 adsorption energy. In addition, during the adsorption process, the atomic orbitals of SAC may hybridize with the orbitals of the reactants [59], and different molecules, such as C2H2 and C2H4, have varying demands for hybridization states, which can affect their adsorption priority. For the selected 7 SACs with phe-S4-G coordination (Fe/phe-S4-G, Co/phe-S4-G, Ni/phe-S4-G, Cu/phe-S4-G, Ru/phe-S4-G, Ir/phe-S4-G and Pt/phe-S4-G), the H atom is stably adsorbed at the C atom; C2H3, CHCH3 and C2H5 species are stably located at the metal sites. For the selected 8 catalysts with pyr-S4-G coordination, H atom is stably adsorbed at the C atom over Ru/pyr-S4-G, Rh/pyr-S4-G, Os/pyr-S4-G and Pt/pyr-S4-G, at the metal sites over Fe/pyr-S4-G, Cu/pyr-S4-G and Ir/pyr-S4-G. C2H3, CHCH3 and C2H5 species are both stably adsorbed at the metal sites. The stable adsorption configurations and energies of these species over M/phe-S4-G and M/pyr-S4-G are presented in Figs. S1, S2 and Table S2. 3.3 H2 adsorption and dissociation In C2H2 selective hydrogenation, H2 adsorption and activation is the key initial step [60], Wu et al. [61] have employed H2 dissociation ability as a criterion to screen out the promising catalysts. Thus, H2 dissociation over above 15 types of screened catalysts are calculated. As shown in Fig. S3, H2 spontaneously dissociates into two H atoms over Fe/phe-S4-G, Co/phe-S4-G, Ni/phe-S4-G, Cu/phe-S4-G, Pt/phe-S4-G, Fe/pyr-S4-G, Rh/pyr-S4-G, Cu/pyr-S4-G, Ru/pyr-S4-G, Pd/pyr-S4-G, Os/pyr-S4-G, Ir/pyr-S4-G and Pt/pyr-S4-G. However, H2 is molecularly adsorbed over Ru/phe-S4-G and Ir/phe-S4-G catalysts, so the dissociation of molecularly adsorbed H2 is further studied, as shown in Fig. S4. The H2 dissociation energy barrier over Ru/phe-S4-G and Ir/phe-S4-G is 171.6 and 46.3 kJ·mol-1, respectively. Based on the subsequent results, it is obtained that on the same catalysts, H2 dissociation is more favorable kinetically than the rate-determining step of C2H2 hydrogenation to C2H4. Namely, the rate-limiting step in the hydrogenation process is not H2 dissociation. Thus, all 15 SACs can provide an abundant hydrogen source for C2H2 selective hydrogenation. 3.4 Hydrogenation and polymerization processes 3.4.1 Possible reaction paths Hydrogenation and polymerization are two processes involved in C2H2 selective hydrogenation, as shown in Fig. 4 . The hydrogenation process consists of three paths [62,63], C2H4 intermediate path, CHCH3 intermediate path and C2H4 desorption path. Among them, the first and second paths mainly produce the by-product C2H6 by C2H2 over-hydrogenation via C2H4 or CHCH3 intermediate. In the third path, C2H4 formation by C2H2 continuous hydrogenation will eventually desorb from the surface to generate gaseous C2H4. Thus, the third path is desired. The polymerization process also consists of three paths, which are the C2H2 self-coupling (C2H2+C2H2), C2H2 coupling with C2H3 (C2H2+C2H3), and C2H3 self-coupling (C2H3+C2H3) [64]. The polymerization process will form 1, 3-butadiene, which is the precursor to produce green oil [65], further covering active site and deactivate the catalyst. Thus, these three paths must be suppressed. 3.4.2 C2H2 hydrogenation process over M/phe-S4-G catalysts As mentioned above, C2H2 adsorption is preferred on the surface of 7 SACs Fe/phe-S4-G, Co/phe-S4-G, Ni/phe-S4-G, Cu/phe-S4-G, Ru/phe-S4-G, Ir/phe-S4-G, and Pt/phe-S4-G. As listed in Table S3, the activation free energy of C2H4+H→C2H5 is higher than C2H4 desorption free energy, which facilitates C2H4 desorption and gaseous C2H4 formation. Thus, possible elementary reactions in the hydrogenation process over these 7 catalysts are calculated, as listed in Table S4. As presented in Fig. 5 , beginning with C2H3+H species, C2H3+H→C2H4 is kinetically preferred compared to C2H3+H→CHCH3 over Fe/phe-S4-G (108.7 vs. 183.1 kJ·mol-1); the same thing also occurs over Co/phe-S4-G (180.1 vs. 193.3 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S5), Ni/phe-S4-G (50.3 vs. 129.5 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S6), Cu/phe-S4-G (91.5 vs. 119.1 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S7), Ir/phe-S4-G (165.9 vs. 299.3 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S9) and Pt/phe-S4-G (165.7 vs. 210.1 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S10), so these 6 catalysts tend to C2H2 hydrogenation to gaseous C2H4. However, C2H3+H→CHCH3 is more kinetically favorable than C2H3+H→C2H4 (210.6 vs. 228.2 kJ·mol-1) over Ru/phe-S4-G (Fig. S8), interestingly, C2H3+H→CHCH3 is more endothermic by 175.7 kJ·mol-1, and CHCH3+H→C2H5 needs a higher activation free energy (187.8 kJ·mol-1), so the total activation free energy of CHCH3 intermediate path is much higher than that of C2H4 desorption path (317.9 vs. 182.6 kJ·mol-1); As a result, the main path of C2H2 selective hydrogenation over Ru/phe-S4-G is C2H4 desorption path to promote C2H4 formation. 3.4.3 C2H2 hydrogenation process over M/pyr-S4-G catalysts Similarly, 8 catalysts (Fe/pyr-S4-G, Cu/pyr-S4-G, Ru/pyr-S4-G, Rh/pyr-S4-G, Pd/pyr-S4-G, Os/pyr-S4-G, Ir/pyr-S4-G and Pt/pyr-S4-G) can achieve the preferential adsorption of C2H2, as shown in Table S3, except for Rh/pyr-S4-G, the activation free energy of C2H4+H→C2H5 over other 7 catalysts are higher than that of C2H4 desorption, which facilitates C2H4 desorption and gaseous C2H4 formation. Thus, possible elementary reactions of hydrogenation process over these 7 catalysts are calculated (Table S4). Similarly, Wang et al. [66] and Li et al. [67] have employed analogous computational methods to calculate the relevant reactions during the hydrogenation process and to conduct subsequent analyses. When the most stable adsorption sites of C2H2 and H species are all the same metal atom, in their co-adsorbed configuration, H atom will be adsorbed at the secondary stable C atom to participate in hydrogenation due to the mutual repulsive interaction between C2H2 and H species. As shown in Figs. S11∼S15, S17, C2H3+H→C2H4 is more kinetically favorable than C2H3+H→CHCH3 on the SACs Fe/pyr-S4-G (45.5 vs. 51.2 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S11), Cu/pyr-S4-G (56.4 vs. 83.5 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S12), Ru/pyr-S4-G (111.8 vs. 143.6 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S13), Pd/pyr-S4-G (154.3 vs. 199.4 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S14), Os/pyr-S4-G (33.7 vs. 34.8 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S15) and Pt/pyr-S4-G (193.6 vs. 279.8 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S17). Thus, these 6 catalysts tend to promote C2H2 hydrogenation to gaseous C2H4. However, over Ir/pyr-S4-G (Fig. S16), firstly, the activation free energy of C2H2+H→C2H3 is 50.1 kJ·mol-1 and exothermic by 131.6 kJ·mol-1; then, beginning with C2H3+H species, the total activation free energies of C2H4 desorption and CHCH3 intermediate paths are 20.3 and −55.4 kJ·mol-1, respectively, namely, CHCH3 intermediate path is kinetically preferred than C2H4 desorption path. Thus, the main path over Ir/pyr-S4-G is CHCH3 intermediate path to present low C2H4 selectivity. 3.5 General discussions 3.5.1 Selectivity and activity over M/phe-S4-G and M/pyr-S4-G catalysts The Eqs. (2) and (3) are used to evaluate C2H4 selectivity, however, the application conditions are different. Since the hydrogenation of C2H3 to form C2H4 and CHCH3 are two competitive reactions, starting from the common intermediate C2H3+H species, when the overall energy barrier of CHCH3 intermediate path (G hydr,CHCH3) is larger than that of C2H4 intermediate path (G hydr,C2H4), namely, CHCH3 intermediate path for C2H2 continuous hydrogenation is not dominant, as shown in Eq. (2) [68,69], C2H4 selectivity can be evaluated by the energy difference with the activation free energy of C2H4+H→C2H5 (G hydr) minus C2H4 desorption free energy (G des). On the contrary, CHCH3 intermediate path is dominant for C2H2 continuous hydrogenation, C2H4 selectivity is determined by the energy difference with the overall energy barrier of CHCH3 intermediate path (G hydr,CHCH3) minus C2H4 desorption path (G hydr,C2H4), as specified in Eq. (3). (2) G sel = G hydr − G des (3) G sel = G hydr , CHCH 3 − G hydr , C 2 H 4 According to the energy span model theory that was previously proposed [70], the activity of catalysts is evaluated via C2H4 production rate, that is the turnover frequency (TOF/site-1∙s-1) obtained by Eq. (4). (4) TOF = k B T h e − E a eff R T Where h stands for the Planck constant, kB represents the Boltzmann constant. R and T are the molar gas constant and the temperature, respectively. Eeff a corresponds to the effective energy barrier of the reaction C2H2+H→C2H4 (see details in the Supplementary Material). For the phe-S4-G coordination (Fig. 6 a), C2H4(g) selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is Pt/phe-S4-G (225.8)>Ir/phe-S4-G (133.5)>Ni/phe-S4-G (85.8)>Co/phe-S4-G (80.8)>Fe/phe-S4-G (78.4)>Cu/phe-S4-G (51.8)>Ru/phe-S4-G (51.5), these 7 SACs favored gaseous C2H4 formation. For the pyr-S4-G coordination (Fig. 6b), C2H4(g) selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is Pt/pyr-S4-G (177.5)>Os/pyr-S4-G (82.0)>Pd/pyr-S4-G (68.5)>Cu/pyr-S4-G (53.3)> Fe/pyr-S4-G (24.1)>Ru/pyr-S4-G (12.2)>Ir/pyr-S4-G (−75.7), the Ir/pyr-S4-G catalyst with a negative value is more likely to take place excessive hydrogenation, which exhibits poor C2H4 selectivity. Thus, in two types of coordination environment, Pt atom located in the 5d period acts as active center to present better C2H4 selectivity, moreover, SACs with phe-S4-G coordination exhibit higher C2H4 selectivity than those with pyr-S4-G coordination. As presented in Fig. 6 and Table 1 , for SACs with phe-S4-G coordination, C2H4 formation activity (TOF/site-1∙s-1) is in sequence of Co/phe-S4-G (1.14 × 10–1)>Cu/phe-S4-G (3.42 × 10–3)>Ni/phe-S4-G (1.13 × 10–8)>Ru/phe-S4-G (7.93 × 10–16)>Fe/phe-S4-G (1.35 × 10–17)>Ir/phe-S4-G (1.58 × 10–19)>Pt/phe-S4-G (2.82 × 10–20), and the Co/phe-S4-G catalyst presents the highest C2H4 formation activity. For SACs with pyr-S4-G coordination, That is Os/pyr-S4-G (2.65 × 1011)>Ir/pyr-S4-G (6.16 × 106)>Cu/pyr-S4-G (3.82 × 103)>Fe/pyr-S4-G (9.03 × 10–1)>Ru/pyr-S4-G (7.48 × 10–2)>Pt/pyr-S4-G (2.24 × 10–3)>Pd/pyr-S4-G (1.23 × 10–14), in which the Os/pyr-S4-G catalyst presents the highest C2H4 formation activity. Above results show that the SACs with phe-S4-G coordination exhibit high C2H4 selectivity, but the activity is generally low, even for Co/phe-S4-G catalyst, the activity is only 1.14 × 10–1 site-1·s-1. On the contrary, compared to SACs with phe-S4-G coordination, SACs with pyr-S4-G coordination have lower C2H4 selectivity, while they have higher C2H4 formation activity. Among them, both Os/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts are found to not only exhibit excellent C2H4 selectivity, but also have high C2H4 formation activity. 3.5.2 Stability of M/phe-S4-G catalyst The polymerization of C2 species can produce C4+ oligomers, further leads to green oil production that covers catalyst surface and deactivate the catalyst to reduce catalyst stability. Since the screened Os/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts present excellent C2H4 selectivity and formation activity, the ability of these two catalysts to inhibit green oil, that is the catalyst stability, is assessed by the difference with the total energy barrier of C2H4 desorption path minus that of the most favorable coupling path, the positive value of energy difference means the preferred occurrence of polymerization process via C2 species coupling path, which fails to prevent green oil, and the catalyst stability is poor. On the contrary, the negative value of energy difference means that the catalyst can inhibit green oil from exhibiting high stability. For the Cu/pyr-S4-G catalyst, as shown in Fig. S12, the most preferred path is C2H4 desorption path in the hydrogenation process. For the polymerization reaction, the C2H3+C2H3 coupling path to generate green oil is kinetically preferred compared to the C2H2+C2H2 and C2H2+C2H3 coupling paths (114.5 vs. 172.5 and 141.8 kJ·mol-1), and the preferred path is the C2H3+C2H3 coupling path, which is kinetically difficult compared to C2H4 desorption path (114.5 vs.76.2 kJ·mol-1). Namely, gaseous C2H4 formation is easier than green oil, thus Cu/pyr-S4-G exhibits good stability. For the Os/pyr-S4-G catalyst, as shown in Fig. S15, the most preferred path is C2H4 desorption path in the hydrogenation process. For the polymerization reaction, the C2H3+C2H3 coupling path is kinetically preferred than the other two coupling paths (12.4 vs. 107.5 and 14.6 kJ·mol-1). Beginning with C2H2 species, the C2H3+C2H3 coupling path has the same total activation free energy with C2H4 desorption path (12.4 kJ·mol-1), However, starting from the same C2H3 intermediate, the reaction C2H3+H→C2H4 (33.7 kJ·mol-1) is kinetically preferred compared to the reaction C2H3+C2H3→C4H6 (104.7 kJ·mol-1), namely, gaseous C2H4 formation is easier than green oil. Thus, the Os/pyr-S4-G catalyst can also exhibit good stability. Above results show that both Cu/pyr-S4-G and Os/pyr-S4-G catalysts can exhibit high C2H4 selectivity and formation activity, as well as better stability to resist green oil production that deactivate the catalyst. 3.5.3 The electronic properties analysis of M/phe-S4-G and M/pyr-S4-G catalysts Previous studies [71,72] obtained that different single-atom metal M anchored on the support with the same coordination environment exhibit significantly different catalytic performance, which is closely related to the electronic structure and affinity of metal. Thus, the electronic properties of M/phe-S4-G and M/pyr-S4-G catalysts are analyzed to clarify the essential reasons for catalytic performance difference. For 7 types of M/phe-S4-G catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7 a, both the metal and its coordinating S atoms lose electron and present a positive charge, while graphene support (G-sub) gains electron and exhibits a negative charge. With the period number increasing of metal atom, the number of electrons lost by metal atom decreases, while that lost by its coordinating S atom increases, and the G-sub gains about 0.6∼0.9 electrons. As shown in Fig. 7b, for 4 types of metal atoms (Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) in the 3d period, as the outermost electron number increases, the d-band center shifts away from the Fermi level (−0.86, −1.06, −1.51 and −2.52 eV). However, for two metal atoms (Ir and Pt) in the 5d period, as the outermost electron number increases, the d-band center shifts toward the Fermi level (−2.32 and −1.51 eV), the d -band center of Ru atom in the 4d period is −1.70 eV For 7 types of M/pyr-S4-G catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7c, when the center atom is Fe, Cu, Ru, Pd or Os, both the metal and its coordinating S atoms lose electrons and take a positive charge, while graphene support (G-sub) gains electrons and takes a negative charge. In the same period, as the outermost d electron number of metal atom increases, the number of electrons lost by the metal atom decreases and that lost by its coordinating S atom increases. When the center atom is Ir or Pt in the 5d period, the metal atoms tend to gain electrons, and the G-sub gains about 0.6∼1.2 electrons. As shown in Fig. 7d, for the Fe and Cu atoms in the 3d period, Ru and Pd atoms in the 4d period, the d-band centers shift away from the Fermi level (−0.81 vs. −2.91 eV and −1.67 vs. −2.72 eV) as the number of outermost electrons increases. For the Os, Ir and Pt atoms in the 5d period, as the outermost electron number increases, d-band center (eV) is Ir/pyr-S4-G (−1.84)<Os/pyr-S4-G (−1.95)<Pt/pyr-S4-G (−2.47). 3.5.4 The nature of metal type and its coordination environment to affect catalytic performance In the SACs, changing the micro-environment of metal atom by adjusting its coordination environment will alter electron density distribution of active center, thereby tuning catalytic performance [73–75]. Since the Fe, Cu, Ru, Ir or Pt atoms with both phe-S4-G and pyr-S4-G coordination environment showed better structure stability, the corresponding electronic properties are investigated. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the differential charge density indicates that the amount of Bader charge transfer for metal is related to its coordination environment. Compared with the catalysts with phe-S4-G coordination environment, when the metal is in the 3d and 4d period, the metal and its coordination S atoms in the catalysts with pyr-S4-G coordination environment lose more electrons; when the metal atoms are in the 5d period, the metal with pyr-S4-G coordination environment lose less electrons and even tend to gain electrons, while the coordination S atoms lose more electrons. In the coordination environment of pyr-S4-G, the M atoms and S atoms are easier to lose electrons compared with the phe-S4-G coordination environment. Meanwhile, the charge transfer amount enhances the interaction between the M metal and S atoms with the graphene support. Thus, the coordination environment of pyr-S4-G has greater stability. On the other hand, the single-atom metal is more protruding from the catalyst surface in the pyr-S4-G compared to that in the phe-S4-G, which reduces the steric hindrance between C2H2 molecule and the M atom in the pyr-S4-G to increase the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the single-atom metals in the pyr-S4-G have a stronger electron attraction ability, which facilitate the π bond activation of C2H2 molecules, thereby increasing the activity of C2H2 hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 8b,c, there is no relationship of average Bader charges transfer amount and d -band center of M atom with C2H4 formation activity over M/phe-S4-G and M/pyr-S4-G catalysts. Thus, it is difficult to describe the C2H4 formation activity solely based on Bader charge transfer amount or the d-band center. However, it is essential to identify an appropriate descriptor that can effectively correlate the structure and electronic properties of the catalyst with catalytic activity. 3.5.5 The proposed descriptor for evaluating catalytic performance Numerous studies showed that the adsorption free energy of key intermediates on the catalyst can be used as an effective descriptor to evaluate catalytic performance [76,77], while the adsorption energy is not easily measured in experiment. In recent years, the activity descriptor has been constructed based on key features of catalytic materials, particularly the coordination properties of metal active center [78]. For example, Ren et al. [79] employed a two-dimensional material loaded dual-atom catalysts (DACs@2D) as a model, in which a simple descriptor including the atomic electronegativity, the type of electrons, and the number of coordination atoms was proposed, which well evaluates the complex interfacial effects on the reactions of CO2, O2 and N2 electrochemical reduction. Wang et al. [80] established a descriptor (φ) including the number of outermost d electrons, electronegativity, coordination number, bond lengths between metal atoms and its nearest neighboring atoms to reflect the intrinsic features of the material, moreover, for the activity of CO2 reduction reaction over N-doped carbon single-atom catalysts (M-N4 C), the volcano relationship between φ and the limiting potentials has been established. Wen et al. [42] defined a descriptor including the electronegativity of metal and its neighboring coordinating atoms, and the occupied ratio of valence electron, which successfully elucidated the activity and selectivity trend of CO2 reduction on the S-coordinated graphene supported transition metal SACs (TM-S4-G-SACs). Based on the screened 14 SACs that can preferentially adsorb C2H2 (Fe/phe-S4-G, Co/phe-S4-G, Ni/phe-S4-G, Cu/phe-S4-G, Ru/phe-S4-G, Ir/phe-S4-G, Pt/phe-S4-G, Fe/pyr-S4-G, Cu/pyr-S4-G, Ru/pyr-S4-G, Pd/pyr-S4-G, Os/pyr-S4-G, Ir/pyr-S4-G and Pt/pyr-S4-G), as shown in Fig. 9 a, b, the descriptor φ (Eq. (5)) is constructed to evaluate C2H4 selectivity and formation activity on the S-doped graphene supported SACs, in which the number of metal outermost d electron, electronegativity, the number of ligand atoms and the bond length are considered. On the other hand, the relationship between electronegativity, bond length, coordination number, and the number of d electrons with the activity of C2H4 production is very complex. Previous studies [81] showed that the electronegativity of the metal center and its coordinating S atoms can affect the interaction between the catalyst and the reactants, and a higher electronegativity of the metal center may lead to stronger metal-S bonds, which facilitate the adsorption and activation of C2H2 and H2 and enhancing the catalytic activity of C2H4 production. Meanwhile, the average bond length between the central metal atom and the coordinating sulfur atoms can affect the stability and reactivity of the catalyst, and an optimal bond length can facilitate the adsorption and activation of reactants [82], which may be favorable for the adsorption and activation of C2H2 and H2, leading to higher activity of C2H4 production. Moreover, the number of sulfur atoms coordinating with the central metal atom can determine the availability and accessibility of active sites on the catalyst surface [83], namely, a higher coordination number can provide more active sites, potentially increasing the catalytic activity of C2H4 production. Furthermore, the number of d electrons in the central metal atom can directly impact the catalytic activity, in which the metals with partially filled d orbitals can interact effectively with reactants [84], facilitating the adsorption and activation of C2H2 and H2 to promote C2H2 hydrogenation to C2H4. (5) φ = ( χ M + d ‾ n s χ S ) + N d Where χM and χS are the electronegativity of the metal M and its coordinated S atoms, respectively;ࣥd is the average bond length between metal atoms and its coordinated S atoms; n S is the number of S atoms coordinated with metal atom; N d is the metal d -electron number. The values of φ for 14 SACs are listed in Table S5. 3.5.6 Descriptor for C2H4 formation activity and selectivity As shown in Fig. 9c, the descriptor φ presents a volcanic relationship with C2H4 formation activity, when the φ values are between 33∼36 and 39∼41, the activity is low, while when the φ values are between 37∼38.5, the Os/pyr-S4-G, Ir/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts present high C2H4 formation activity. As shown in Fig. 9d, the descriptor φ has a strong linear correlation with C2H4 adsorption free energy, as φ increases, C2H4 adsorption strength decreases. Meanwhile, the descriptor φ has an inverted volcanic relationship with C2H4 selectivity (Fig. 9e); the Pt/phe-S4-G, Ir/phe-S4-G and Pt/pyr-S4-G catalysts present high C2H4 selectivity with the φ value range between 33∼34 or 39∼40. Above analysis shows that the descriptor φ can quickly and qualitatively evaluate the effect of metal M type and its coordination environment on C2H4 formation activity and selectivity over S-doped graphene supported metal SACs. 3.6 The thermal stability evaluation of Cu/pyr-S4-G and Os/pyr-S4-G catalysts As mentioned above, the screened Cu/pyr-S4-G and Os/pyr-S4-G catalysts present high C2H4 selectivity and formation activity, and better ability to inhibit green oil in C2H2 selective hydrogenation, however, up to now, the thermal stability of Os/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts has not been reported in the previous experiment, thus, this study employes AIMD simulations to assess the thermal stability of catalysts and provide insights into the catalyst's structure behavior and potential performance in practical applications [85,86]. As shown in Fig. 10 , the thermal stability of Os/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts at 425 K is further investigated by using AIMD simulations, which includes two main stages. The first stage involves simulating the thermal stability of the catalyst as it is gradually heated from 0 K to 425 K. The second stage simulates the thermal stability of the catalyst at the reaction temperature of 425 K. In fact, the AIMD simulation process is analogous to the temperature program process in experiment [87,88], which involves the process of heating the catalyst sample to a specific temperature and maintaining the temperature for a period to ensure that the active sites on the catalyst surface reach the thermal equilibrium. AIMD simulations show that as time varies, energy and temperature initially rise to an equilibrium state and then fluctuate around this equilibrium state, there is no obvious structure change of the catalyst, the center Cu and Os atoms remain stable. After a 10,000 fs simulation, the catalyst still remains stable, proving that the catalyst has good thermal stability under the realistic reaction temperature of 425 K. Thus, the Cu/pyr-S4-G and Os/pyr-S4-G catalysts good thermal stability. 3.7 Feasibility of preparing S-doped graphene supported SACs S-doped graphene supported metal SACs has been successfully prepared in experiment, and the most convenient method is directly pyrolyzing S-containing precursors and then anchoring metal atoms, especially for some high thermal stability S-containing polymers, they can be directly turned into S-C supports through high-temperature pyrolysis and carbonization [41]. Another similar method is to deposit C2H2/H2S chemical vapor on the zeolite template carbon at lower temperature, and then treat it with H2S at higher temperature to obtain a microporous S-C support with high surface area (2800 m2 g-1) and a very high S content (17 wt%) [89]. Pyrolysis or chemical treatment of carbon supports can be used to achieve S doping. Durante et al. [43] prepared S-C supports by secondary pyrolysis of carbon materials using dibenzothiophene as the S source. Treatment of graphite oxide with H2S at high temperature also achieved S doping [45]. Furthermore, by impregnating a S-C support in chloroplatinic acid and then performing H2 reduction at 300 °C and 700 °C, respectively, Yan et al. [21] prepared both Pt single-atom and Pt nanoclusters catalysts with 5 wt% Pt loading. Yang et al. [19] used Co-assisted pyrolysis method to prepare the S-C support with slight modifications and subsequently anchoring Ru ions into S-C support to synthesize Ru-S-C SACs. Thus, these previously reported studies indirectly confirmed that both Cu/pyr-S4-G and Os/pyr-S4-G catalysts should be able to be experimentally prepared. 4 Conclusions In this study, density functional theory calculations and AIMD simulations are used to investigate the effects of single-atom metal M types (M=Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Os, Ir, Pt and Au) and its coordination environments (phe-S4-G and pyr-S4-G) on catalytic performance of C2H2 selective hydrogenation over 24 types of S-doped graphene supported SACs. The results show that, the catalysts with Pt atom in the 5d period as active center show the highest C2H4 selectivity in two coordination environments. M/phe-S4-G catalysts have high C2H4 selectivity but low C2H4 formation activity, M/pyr-S4-G catalysts have high C2H4 formation activity but low C2H4 selectivity. The electronic properties analysis shows that modulating metal M type and its coordination environment can change electronic properties of metal atom and charge transfer between metal atoms and its coordination atoms, which would affect adsorption ability of the reactants and intermediates and further tune catalytic performance. The amount of Bader charge transfer and d-band center of single-atom metal show the inverted volcanic and volcanic relationship with C2H4 formation activity, respectively. The descriptor φ=(χM+ࣥdnSχS)+N d is established by considering the metal outermost d electron number, electronegativity, the number of ligand S atoms and the bond length. The descriptor φ has a volcanic curve with C2H4 formation activity, a linear relationship with C2H4 adsorption ability, and an inverted volcanic curve with C2H4 selectivity, which can be used to quickly and qualitatively evaluate C2H4 selectivity and formation activity. The screened Os/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts not only present good structural and thermal stability, but also have excellent C2H4 selectivity and formation activity, as well as better ability to inhibit green oil that deactivate the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: S-doped graphene supported SACs exhibited better catalytic performance for many heterogeneous reactions with adjustable electronic properties of single-atom active center. This work investigates C2H2 selective hydrogenation on a series of S-doped graphene supported SACs to unravel the roles of single-atom type and its coordination environment in tuning catalytic performance. It is found that the intrinsic reasons affecting catalytic activity are attributed to that different metal M type and its coordination environment led to different Bader charge transfer and d-band center, and further affect adsorption ability of reactants and intermediates to tune catalytic performance. The descriptor φ=(χM+ࣥdnSχS)+N d was constructed in the S-doped graphene supported SACs, which can quickly and qualitatively evaluate C2H4 formation activity and selectivity, and further increase design efficiency of high-performance SACs. The screened Os/pyr-S4-G and Cu/pyr-S4-G catalysts not only exhibit good selectivity, activity and ability to inhibit green oil, but also present good structural and thermal stability.
